repnme.cdata!:
Romania - Private and Public Sector
            Institution Building Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Private and Public
            Sector Institution Building Loan Project (PPIBL) for Romania
            were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            restructure projects when needed, especially when moving
            from Technical Assistance (TA) to an investment project and
            when parallel financing is mobilized so that each project
            could be evaluated on its own merits and so that the
            Government resources will not be wasted on undisbursed
            funds. The PPIBL was not restructured to reflect the de
            facto significantly changed Project Development Objective
            (PDO), project financing, as well as expenditure category
            and component cost allocations. This made the PPIBL funds
            initially redundant; it led to disbursement delays as the
            Government of Romania (GoR) preferred to withdraw the
            existing grant and loan funds before or instead of the
            PPIBL; and it made the GoR pay commitment fees for
            unutilized funds until 2005. It also complicated the project
            evaluation that needed to cover all the sources of funding
            and made it somewhat artificial as no clear accountability
            lines were drawn between the Bank-related sources of funding
            since they were managed as a pool of funds. The GoR
            maintained an experienced and sufficiently staffed Project
            Management Unit (PMU) throughout the project life and
            established a high level Programmatic Adjustment Loan (PAL)
            PMU to monitor the preparation and implementation of the PAL
            reform progress in 2004-2006. The location of the PAL PMU
            and the cooperation between the PMU provided the required
            leverage to launch and expedite the project implementation
            because many of the beneficiary agencies had limited
            institutional capacity and readiness to embark in the reform
            program; they had limited or even absent experience with
            Bank's projects; and there was a need for coordinated
            intergovernmental efforts.

repnme.cdata!:
Romania - Private and Public Sector
            Institution Building Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The goal of the Private and Public
            Sector Institution Building Loan Project (PPIBL) is to
            provide the required techncial assistance to implement the
            policy measures which will be supported by the Second
            Private Sector Adjustment Loan Project (PSAL II) (report no.
            P7507), and to lay the ground for the reforms that will be
            implemented under the proposed Programmatic Adjustment Loan
            (PAL). The project has five project components. The first,
            the Financial Sector Restructuring and Privatization Support
            component, provides technical assistance to restructure CEC
            (savings Bank) in preparation for privatization; develops
            capital markets by strengthening legislation, regulatory
            capacity and infrastructure; strenthens the capital markts
            regulatory agencies; and strengthens insurance supervision.
            The second component supports privatization of the ten
            largest state enterprises. The third component provides
            technical assistance for the divestiture of key enterprises
            in the oil, gas, and electricity/power sectors, including
            majority or strategic sales under market conditions. The
            fourth component supports an improved business environment
            and covers training of judges and court personnel,
            procurement of court equipment, refurbishing works, and a
            public awareness campaign. The fifth component strengthens
            institutional and governance reform.
